Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: iPS Cells with Nanofibrous Scaffolds for Spinal Cord Regeneration

POR.DRECONTENT:
Spinal cord injury leads to, among other things, cavity formation that interrupts the directional architecture of the cord and cell death (i.e., neurons, oligodendrocytes, and precursor cells). Considering this, a successful therapy will likely include new structural support for directed axon guidance as well as replacement cells. Electrospun nanofibrous scaffolds present a potential platform to help rebuild this lost architecture. Electrospinning is a technique that uses an applied electric field to draw out fibers of submicron to micron diameter from viscoelastic substances (e.g., a poly-l-lactide polymer dissolved in an organic solvent), creating biodegradable scaffolds that closely mimic the topography of the extracellular matrix. With the alignment of these fibers, greater control over cell orientation, migration, and process outgrowth can be achieved. Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) are a population of adult cells that have been genetically reprogrammed to a pluripotent state, having the ability to differentiate into progeny characteristic of all three germ layers. These cells are of great interest because they mitigate much of the ethical and immunogenicity concerns that arise with embryonic stem cell therapies. This research aims to explore how the topography of nanofibrous scaffolds influence iPSC behavior and differentiation into cell types relevant to neural regeneration. Also, towards the goal of spinal cord repair, this work looks to demonstrate how nanofibrous scaffolds may enhance iPSC generation and neurite outgrowth from iPSC-derived neurospheres. Through this project we were able to demonstrate the feasibility of adult human dermal fibroblast transfection by the controlled release of cationic lipid-DNA plasmid complexes from negatively charged nanofiber scaffolds. This work aims to improve the ease somatic cell reprogramming using non-integrating plasmid transfection methods. In addition, we showed that nanofiber scaffold alignment can improve axon outgrowth from hiPSC-derived neurospheres by 2 fold.


Last Modified: 12/02/2010
Modified by: Timothy L Downing

    Scaffold's aligned nanofibrous topography promotes (unidirectional) neurite outgrowth
